text.p: Suppose [mathjaxinline]S: \mathbb R^ n \rightarrow \mathbb R^ m[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation. Let [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^ n \rightarrow \mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline] be the identity transformation (recall that this means [mathjaxinline]T(v) = v[/mathjaxinline] for all [mathjaxinline]v\in \mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline]).
Which of the following is true?

solution.font: First, [mathjaxinline]T\circ S[/mathjaxinline] is undefined because [mathjaxinline]S[/mathjaxinline] outputs a vector in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ m[/mathjaxinline], and the domain of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline]. Now, for every vector [mathjaxinline]v\in \mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]S\circ T(v)=S(T(v))=S(v)[/mathjaxinline] because [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] acts as the identity transformation. Therefore [mathjaxinline]S\circ T=S[/mathjaxinline].
